themes: long-term trust-building and power-sharing with artists and cultural leaders
funding cultural ecosystems rather than individual projects
support for artist-led organizations, mutual aid networks, and informal collectives
meaningful feedback loops and participatory governance
prioritizing equity for marginalized communities (BIPOC, LGBTQ+, disabled, youth, immigrant creatives)
the importance of accessibility, responsiveness, and human-centered approaches
redefining public cultural support as stewardship and collective care
key_phrases: center is long-term trust-building and power-sharing
support artist-led organizations, mutual aid networks, community venues, and informal collectives
artists and cultural workers are involved after the survey stage
Prioritize the communities most impacted by displacement, erasure, and underfunding
Equity isn’t just a value it’s a measurable outcome
not just as a gatekeeper of resources, but as a steward of collective care, shared power, and visionary imagination
barriers_identified: little to no institutional support for artists, organizers, and cultural leaders
displacement, erasure, and underfunding of marginalized communities
lack of meaningful involvement of artists and cultural workers in decision-making
solutions_proposed: center long-term trust-building and power-sharing with existing cultural leaders
fund cultural ecosystems including artist-led organizations, mutual aid networks, community venues, and informal collectives
create feedback loops that involve artists and cultural workers in advisory boards, selection committees, co-designing programs, and accountability structures
prioritize funding and support for communities most impacted by displacement, erasure, and underfunding (BIPOC, LGBTQ+, disabled, youth, immigrant creatives)
adopt accessible, responsive, and people-first approaches
redefine public cultural support as stewardship and collective care
